docs.abstract: The latest Covid surge has highlighted the essential skills provided by Broadway’s swings and understudies.
docs.snippet: The latest Covid surge has highlighted the essential skills provided by Broadway’s swings and understudies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the swings and understudies who have been vital to Broadway during the Omicron surge. We’ll also examine why Mayor-elect Eric Adams may have held off on naming a former high-ranking police official to a City Hall post. And we’ll run the Metropolitan Diary item that readers chose as the best of the year.

headline.main: The Show Will Go On, Thanks to Them

docs.abstract: Mutual aid fulfills needs, but it also builds stronger, more resilient communities.
docs.snippet: Mutual aid fulfills needs, but it also builds stronger, more resilient communities.
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Holiday Giving Guide 2021. For other ideas on where to donate this year, please see the rest of our guide here.

docs.abstract: Teenage comments in response to a question about this and two more writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.snippet: Teenage comments in response to a question about this and two more writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.lead_paragraph: This week on The Learning Network, one of our writing prompts asked teenagers if parents should ever be held responsible for a school shooting. Over 100 weighed in with thoughtful responses.

headline.main: What Students Are Saying About the Parents’ Role in a Recent School Shooting

docs.abstract: Commissioner Dermot Shea and his first deputy, Benjamin Tucker, each served in the Police Department for more than two decades.
docs.snippet: Commissioner Dermot Shea and his first deputy, Benjamin Tucker, each served in the Police Department for more than two decades.
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City police commissioner and his top deputy have both filed papers to retire at the end of the year, after long careers that will end during one of the most tumultuous periods in the department’s history.

headline.main: N.Y.P.D. Commissioner and First Deputy File for Retirement

byline.original: By Ashley Southall and Troy Closson

docs.abstract: In a year that offered glimmers of hope across the world of arts, these performers and creators rose to the occasion.
docs.snippet: In a year that offered glimmers of hope across the world of arts, these performers and creators rose to the occasion.
docs.lead_paragraph: The cultural world began to sputter back to life this year, and in turn, so did many of us — slipping out of our sweats and into movie theaters, clubs and Broadway shows. Even for those who were less confident rubbing (or bumping) elbows in public, artists brought us plenty of joy in the safety of our home. It may not have been the beforetimes, but in 2021, these artists and creators from across the arts gave us a fresh outlook.

headline.print_headline: Breakout Artists Who Enriched the Year

docs.abstract: Police stops are down, but homelessness endures. Schools remain segregated, but there are 60,000 prekindergarten slots.
docs.snippet: Police stops are down, but homelessness endures. Schools remain segregated, but there are 60,000 prekindergarten slots.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Bill de Blasio first ran for mayor in 2013, he pledged to reduce inequality in an increasingly opulent New York City where he argued poor residents were falling behind.

headline.main: 6 Numbers That Reveal Bill de Blasio’s Legacy on Inequality

docs.abstract: This HBO documentary goes behind the scenes of the Public Theater’s post-shutdown, modern adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” featuring an all-Black cast.
docs.snippet: This HBO documentary goes behind the scenes of the Public Theater’s post-shutdown, modern adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” featuring an all-Black cast.
docs.lead_paragraph: Rudy Valdez’s documentary, “Reopening Night,” takes viewers behind the scenes of “Merry Wives,” the Public Theater’s first production after the coronavirus pandemic shut down Broadway and other venues until earlier this year.

headline.main: ‘Reopening Night’ Review: The Show Goes On

docs.abstract: “Family Matters” at the ICP captures the inevitability of families fractured over politics.
docs.snippet: “Family Matters” at the ICP captures the inevitability of families fractured over politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Someone has left in a hurry. The signs are there in the photograph: the open drawers, the improperly rolled tissue paper, the white electric cable peeking out from underneath the counter. The walls and floors are covered with marble — reflecting light, intensifying the room’s emptiness. Through the window, outside, tall slim trees give the house a sense of scale and location — it is easy to imagine that this is an outsize property in an area far from where everyday people live.

headline.main: Gillian Laub’s Divided House Is Still Standing. What About Yours?
headline.print_headline: The Family Ties That Can Choke

docs.abstract: The season’s latest releases take up the New England Patriots, the origin story of Giannis Antetokounmpo — and the role of discrimination, protests and money in the world of athletics.
docs.snippet: The season’s latest releases take up the New England Patriots, the origin story of Giannis Antetokounmpo — and the role of discrimination, protests and money in the world of athletics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sports fans can easily forget or dismiss a clear reality about the games they love: They are a form of entertainment, a business endeavor competing among many options for emotional and financial attention.

headline.main: They’ve Got Game: New Sports Books

docs.abstract: Kerby Jean-Raymond has spent the last year and a half secretly trying to change the game for minority designers.
docs.snippet: Kerby Jean-Raymond has spent the last year and a half secretly trying to change the game for minority designers.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, when the United States was being roiled by the aftermath of the George Floyd murder and businesses of all kinds were coming face to face with their own systemic racism, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder and designer of Pyer Moss, who has used his brand to shed light on Black history as well as police brutality, began to get a lot of calls.

headline.main: Meet the Next Big Fashion Group
headline.print_headline: Giving Designers Of Color Their Due

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Your Friends in New York (Fashion Collective)
